El Kabeir hangs on to win Ky. Jockey Club

Jennie Rees, jrees@courier-journal.com 7:57 p.m. EST November 29, 2014

El Kabeir (right) holds off Imperia (center) and Eagle to capture the Kentucky Jockey Club at Churchill Downs.(Photo: Reed Palmer Photography/Churchill Downs)

15 CONNECT 12 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Trainer John Terranova wished going in that he could have gotten one more work into El Kabeir before Saturday’s $233,000 Kentucky Jockey Club at Churchill Downs. And he really wished that watching the final 70 yards as El Kabeir’s once-comfortable lead shrank with every stride as the hard-charging Imperia came flying to put the outcome very much in doubt.

“C’mon Calvin, keep finding,” Terranova said, referring to jockey Calvin Borel as he watched the race from the rail. “C’mon, boy. Wiiiiire!!”

“Think you got it,” he was told.

“Uh, maybe. Close.”

But the short horse loomed tall after El Kabeir hung on for a head victory in the Grade II stakes, paying $16.60 to win as the third choice. Eagle also closed well to finishing another three-quarters of a length back in third in the field of 11 two-year-olds. The Bob Baffert-trained Lord Nelson, the 7-5 favorite, bobbled at the start to take him out of his up-close running style, then had to come very wide while finishing fifth.

Terranova and owner Zayat Stables opted for the 1 1/16-mile Kentucky Jockey Club over the $400,000 Remsen at 1 1/8 miles back in New York. They liked the shorter distance for a horse running around two turns and farther than a mile for the first time. And it didn’t hurt that it’s at the home of next spring’s Kentucky Derby, for which El Kabeir picked up 10 points toward qualifying.

In another nice perk, needing a jockey, they were able to secure Borel, the three-time Kentucky Derby winner who now is a four-time Kentucky Jockey Club winner.

“I thought, ‘Who knows Churchill better? And who can get them to relax?’” Terranova said.

So even though El Kabeir went the half-mile in 47.50 seconds – slow for the leader if you have a horse who comes from off the pace, but fast enough if you’re the one setting it – Terranova wasn’t worried. At least at that stage.

“He’s a real fast colt and looked real relaxed with Calvin,” he said, adding of Lord Nelson, “It looks like Bob’s horse didn’t break well, and I thought, ‘If they’re going to leave him alone on the lead, that’s great.’”

The Kiaran McLaughlin-trained Imperia, in his first dirt race, came flying under Robby Albarado. El Kabeir barely held sway while covering 1 1/16 miles in 1:44.82.

“At the finish, I knew it was getting tight, because he had never been this far and the track is a little heavy,” Borel said. “Everything put together, it was a matter of who could grind the other one… After this race, it will tighten him up real good.”

“One more jump and he had it,” McLaughlin, speaking by phone from New York but well represented at Churchill with his Kentucky relatives, said of Imperia. “But he ran great and we’re tickled. We belong with the 3-year-olds moving forward to the first Saturday in May.”

El Kabeir, a gray son of Scat Daddy, was third in his debut at Saratoga, then won his next start by 10 ¾ lengths. His Breeders’ Cup Juvenile aspirations were dashed by a well-beaten fourth in the Grade I Champagne in torrential slop, followed by a well-beaten second in the mud in the Grade II Nashua after setting a fast pace while wearing blinkers. The blinkers came off for this race.

“This horse, for us, was actually a work short,” Justin Zayat, racing manager for his father, Ahmed, said by phone from New Jersey. “… We said, ‘Why not take a shot? He’s a little short, but he’s got the talent to do it.’”

Zayat Stables also has double Grade I winner American Pharoah, scratched from the Breeders’ Cup Juvenile with a deep foot bruise, and Mr. Z, who lost the $1 million Delta Downs Jackpot by a nose, among its 2-year-olds.

“American Pharoah, to me, is in a class of his own,” Justin Zayat said. “But straight up honesty, Mr. Z is closing very hard on him, and El Kabeir … is going to be right there.”

Golden Rod – West Coast Belle ran her record to 3 for 3, closing from mid-pack to win the $230,400 stakes by 1 ¼ lengths over the late-running No Fault of Mine. The battle-ship gray daughter of the Gainesway Farm stallion Tapit covered 1 1/16 miles in 1:45.52, paying $5.20 as the 8-5 favorite. She was ridden for the first time by Shaun Bridgmohan.

“She’s getting better all the time,” said trainer Wayne Catalano, who won three races Saturday to come into Churchill’s closing card Sunday tied at 13 wins apiece for the trainers title with Dale Romans, who also won three.

West Coast Belle was bred by owners Gary and Mary West. “That makes it extra special,” Gary West said. “Shaun said she really is push-button, will just relax and go and when it’s time to go.”

The Golden Rod was worth 10 points toward qualifying for next spring’s Kentucky Oaks. “She’s a good enough filly,” Gary West said, “It’s just a matter of keeping her sound and healthy.”

It was another 6 ¼ lengths back to Heart’s Song in third in the field of 12 two-year-old fillies.

Contact Jennie Rees at 502-582-4042. Follow her on Twitter @CJ_Jennie and Facebook.com/CJJennie
